What did early Canadian pioneer wives do?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Elizabeth Harrison
Address: 402 Creek Road
Birthplace: West Point, Iowa

1. HOUSEHOLD BUSINESSES
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Maple Creek, Sask.
   Where had you been living before that? Billings, Montana
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Three
   How far was it to your nearest store? Four miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? As often as you liked
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Agar's
   In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred lbs.
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
   How much did you use graham flour? None
   Whole wheat flour? None
   Was flour milled locally? No
   How far away? What year? 1876
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use? Oats, buckwheat, cornmeal
   Cornmeal? Yellow cornmeal
   Whole wheat? None
   Farina? None
   Other? None
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some times
   How did you grind it? With a coffee mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? One hundred lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 16 cts.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? Around thirty cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? By milk cows.

Butter? Home-made.

Eggs? Curved farm.

What was the price of butter? 7½ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Salt pork, bacon.

How did you get fresh meat? Cured it.

How often did you get fresh meat? Quite often.

How did you preserve meat? Trussed, packed, put in jars and covered it with hard molasses.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Rabbits.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Meat very often.

Was it hard to get white fish shipped in?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? White fish, Jack fish.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.00
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from?
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1922 Cabbage 1925 Carrots 1928 Onions 1924
Turnips 1920 Beets 1924
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 20 lbs
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes
What was the price of prunes? Around 50 cents
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Apples Apricots Peaches Raisins Oranges

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes
Peas? Yes Corn? Yes Beans? No Saskatoons? No
Other foods?
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? The first year
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1911
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? About 1911
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
To what extent? Some
Did you make your own vinegar? Some

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ____________ Aug. area rain. Well.

How far was this water from your home? _______ about 100 yds.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) _______ Pail & Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We moved to town in 1904.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, stream, etc.)

Water was brought to the house by (well, barrel, tank).

How far was this water from your home?

Was it brought to the house by (well, barrel, tank).

Has any other supply been used which have taken place since you first started homesteading?

We moved to town in 1947.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Making my own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... good ash?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Purchased at Linn's Mill.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We used wood and coal along until 1943 we use fuel oil to heat, and coal in Cook Stove.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Used wood in Cook Stove.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? 

What year was it purchased? 1908. Price? $27.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Stone, tin, and Homco ware china.

For preparing food? (chips, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

China, earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? 1914.

Aluminum? 1920.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Never relied on the Prep and one always had my own
